snp3.2:425: “When, resolved upon striving,I had gone to the Nerañjarā River,as I was meditating very strenuouslyto attain security from bondage, (1)
snp3.2:426: “Namucī approached me,speaking compassionate words:‘You are thin, pale;you’re on the verge of death. (2)
snp3.2:427: “ ‘A thousand parts belong to death,one fraction of your life remains.Live, sir, life is better!While living, make merits! (3) [75]
snp3.2:428: “ ‘While you are living the spiritual lifeand performing the fire sacrifice,abundant merit is stored up.Why devote yourself to striving? (4)
snp3.2:429: “ ‘Hard to travel is the path for striving,hard to practice, hard to achieve.’ ”Speaking these verses, Māra stoodin the presence of the Buddha. (5)
snp3.2:430: When Māra had spoken in such a way,the Blessed One said this to him:“Kinsman of the heedless, Evil One,you have come here with a purpose. (6)
snp3.2:431: “I do not have any needeven for the slightest merit.I read withCeandEeaṇumattenapi puññena attho, as againstBeaṇumattopi puññena attho.It is fitting for Māra to speakto those who have need of merits. (7)
snp3.2:432: “I have faith and energy too,and wisdom exists in me.When I am so resolute,why do you ask me to live? (8)
snp3.2:433: “This wind might dry upeven the streams of the rivers,so why, when I am resolute,should it not dry up my blood? (9)
snp3.2:434: “When the blood is drying up,the bile and phlegm dry up.When my muscles are wasting away,my mind becomes even more serene,and my mindfulness and wisdomand concentration become more firm. (10)
snp3.2:435: “While I am dwelling in such a wayI have experienced extreme pain,yet my mind does not turn to sensual pleasures:behold the purity of the being! (11) [76]
snp3.2:436: “Sensual pleasures are your first army;the second is called discontent.Hunger and thirst are the third;the fourth is called craving. (12)
snp3.2:437: “The fifth is dullness and drowsiness;the sixth is called cowardice.Doubt is your seventh;your eighth, denigration and pride. (13)
snp3.2:438: “Gain, praise, and honor,and wrongly obtained fame [is ninth];[the tenth is when] one extols oneselfand looks down at others. (14)
snp3.2:439: “This is your army, Namucī,the squadron of the Dark One.A weakling does not conquer it,but having conquered it, one gains bliss. (15)
snp3.2:440: “I wear muñja grass;wretched would life be to me.I read withBeandCe, and all three editions ofPj II,dhiratthu mama jīvitaṃ.Eehasidhaformama.It’s better that I die in battlethan live on defeated. (16)
snp3.2:441: “Some ascetics and brahmins,engulfed here, are no longer seen.They do not know the path by whichthe disciplined ones travel. (17)
snp3.2:442: “Having seen the bannered army all around,[and] Māra with his vehicle ready,I will go out to meet him in battle:may he not dislodge me from my place! (18)
snp3.2:443: “Though the world with its devascannot overcome that army of yours, [77]I will destroyI read withBebhecchāmi, corresponding tobhetsyāmiat Mvu II 240,11.CeandEehavegacchāmi.it with wisdom,like a fresh clay bowl with a stone. (19)
snp3.2:444: “Having gained mastery over my intention,and with mindfulness well established,I will wander from realm to realm,guiding many disciples. (20)
snp3.2:445: “Heedful and resolute,those practitioners of my teaching,against your wishes, will goto the state where one does not sorrow.” (21)
snp3.2:446: “For seven years I followed the Blessed One,[trailing him] step by step,but I have not found an openingin the Enlightened One, who is mindful. (22)
snp3.2:447: “There was a crow that circled arounda stone that looked like a lump of fat:‘Perhaps we’ll find something tender here;perhaps there may be something tasty.’ (23)
snp3.2:448: “But finding nothing tasty there,the crow departed from that place.Just like the crow that attacked the stone,we leave Gotama disappointed.” (24) [78]
snp3.2:449: So much was he stricken with sorrowthat his lute fell from his armpit.Thereupon that saddened spiritdisappeared right on the spot. (25)
